Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Effects of Nutrient Enrichment and Salinization on the Fate and Persistence of Soil Organic Matter in Tidal Freshwater Wetlands
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coastal wetlands are a globally significant sink for carbon due to high rates of plant growth and low rates of microbial organic matter breakdown. These ecosystems, however, are increasingly threatened by salinization, nutrient enrichment and other human disturbances. Salinization and nutrient enrichment are known to alter plant growth and microbial breakdown, however there is uncertainty regarding their effect on the carbon balance of coastal wetlands. Changes in plant and microbial communities brought on by human disturbances may lead to either increased net carbon release from wetland soils or to increased storage of carbon as soil organic matter. The soil organic matter pool, therefore, reflects feedbacks between plants and microbes and integrates them over long time-scales, providing a useful tool for assessing the cumulative impacts of salinization and nutrient enrichment on the wetland carbon cycle. In order to assess the impacts of salinization and nutrient enrichment on wetland carbon cycling, soil will be collected from tidal freshwater wetlands in coastal Georgia where either salinity or nutrients have been experimentally increased above natural levels. In addition, the interactive effects of salinization and nutrient enrichment will be explored by transplanting vegetated soil cores between nutrient-enriched and salinized wetland sites. Soils will be incubated for one year and analyzed for changes in 1) quantity and composition of soil organic matter 2) microbial demand for different types of soil organic matter and 3) rates of microbial organic matter breakdown. Results from this study will be integrated with previously collected data on plant and microbial processes at each site.

This research contributes to a fundamental understanding of ecosystem scale carbon cycling by examining two of the most common human activities affecting wetlands on a global scale: salinization resulting from rising sea level and freshwater management, and nutrient runoff from agricultural activities. Understanding the impacts of these disturbances is important for protecting wetland ecosystems and maintaining their ability to provide key ecosystem services, such as carbon sequestration and wildlife habitat. Environmental science and policy students from the School of Public and Environmental Affairs at Indiana University and k-12 educators from the Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER Schoolyard Program will be involved in all aspects of this study. The implications of this research will be discussed as part of the School?s Wetlands Biology and Regulation course. Results will be communicated in scientific meetings, peer-reviewed publications and directly to coastal Georgia residents and resource managers through ongoing collaborations with the Sapelo Island National Estuarine Research Reserve, The Nature Conservancy and the Georgia Department of Natural Resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soil organic matter is a globally significant sink for carbon (C) and the dominant contributor to vertical accretion in tidal freshwater wetlands. However, there are still significant uncertainties regarding the processes controlling the fate and persistence of soil organic matter, particularly as wetlands experience increasing anthropogenic disturbance such as seawater intrusion or increased nutrient loads. In a suite of field and laboratory experiments, we investigated how seawater intrusion and increased nitrogen (N) loads alter tidal freshwater marsh soil organic matter through (1) short-term direct effects of changes in the abiotic soil environment, and (2) longer-term indirect effects mediated via changes in productivity and microbial community. Results from this work suggest that in short-term studies, these two perturbations accelerate mineralization by introducing more energetically favorable anaerobic mineralization pathways, nitrate reduction (N enrichment) and sulfate reduction (seawater intrusion). However, we find that this short-term increase in mineralization does not reduce total soil C (Fig. 1), but does suppress the production of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas. Significant changes in soil C were associated with long-term shifts in plant community and productivity. Long-term N enrichment decreased allocation to root biomass and reduces soil C:N ratios, enhances microbial activity, and results in lower soil C after a decade (Fig. 1). Long-term seawater intrusion results in reduced primary productivity, increased mineralization and N export from soils, and results in lower soil C after a decade. Our study suggest that soil carbon responses are driven by long term processes, while the greenhouse gas balance of a wetland may change rapidly after a disturbance.

Increased salinity and N are expected to co-occur in many estuaries. In the lab, a combination of salinization and N enrichment cumulatively increased CO2 production more than either treatment alone. While we hypothesized this synergistic effect is a result of excess  N  alleviating the N limitations that develop in salinized soils, we did not see any reductions in soil C from a 1 year incubation of fertilized soil cores in a salinized marsh, therefore the long-term consequences of this combination of stressors is unresolved. However, In both field and laboratory experiments,  the combination of  seawater and N  resulted in increased N2O production from incubated soils (up to 1000%), suggesting that the interaction of these two perturbations may be more detrimental to the greenhouse gas balance of tidal freshwater marshes than either alone. 

This research contributes to a fundamental understanding of ecosystem scale C cycling by examining two of the most common human activities affecting wetlands on a global scale: salinization resulting from rising sea level and freshwater management, and nutrient runoff from agricultural activities. Understanding the impacts of these disturbances is important for protecting wetland ecosystems and maintaining their ability to provide key ecosystem services, such as C sequestration and water quality improvement. Two environmental  science and policy Master’s students from the School of Public and Environmental Affairs at Indiana University were trained in laboratory and field methodology as part of this project. The results from this study were presented in one Doctoral dissertation and are currently being prepared for submission as two peer-reviewed publications. These results were the basis of invited talks at two international scientific meetings and three invited university seminars.
